newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Feisty Hong Kong fund puts wind up Hambros.
newsitem.headline: Feisty Hong Kong fund puts wind up Hambros.

text.p: Like a piranha circling a whale, the small but tenacious Regent Pacific Group Ltd is relentlessly pursuing Hambros Plc

"If a company puts itself into the public arena and is owned by shareholders, then it has to be accountable to shareholders for its performance," Regent Pacific managing director James Mellon told Reuters in an interview this past week.
The venerable investment bank is just the latest prey for Regent, often called a "vulture fund", reflecting its predatory nature.
Rather than buying up distressed debt at discount prices as most vulture funds do, Regent tries to rip apart under- performing investment funds to return value to unit holders.
"The only reason it (Regent) gets aggressive is because an undervalued situation (is) like an oyster. You have to prise it open to get to the pearl," Mellon said.
Often, this means having to battle past unwilling management, he said.
Founded in 1990, Regent Pacific is a mid-sized Asian investment fund company with US$2 billion under management.

In addition to managing a variety of its own retail funds and Asian-dedicated portolios for larger institutions, a total of US$1.3 billion of Regent Pacific's assets are held in "under-valued asset" funds dedicated to closed-end funds and Australian property trusts.
Run by a group of tough-minded executives, Regent Pacific usually generates more headlines than the rest of Hong Kong's investment community put together.
"This company is not out to pick fights, even though it might look like that at the moment," Mellon said.
"This company is out to make as much money as possible on our equity and that is what every company should be doing."
Following a couple of small successes, Regent Pacific has recently became embroiled in high-profile battles with Pioneer Industries International (Holdings) Ltd and now with Hambros.
Earlier this month, Hong Kong-listed Pioneer managed to fend off Regent's attempts to force a sale of its primary holding, a 3.77 percent stake in Bangkok Bank, Thailand's biggest bank.

Accusations by Regent, including an allegation Pioneer's shares were trading at a 60 percent discount to net asset value, has seen them fall to 5.30 from 5.90 when the tussle started. Pioneer's stake has now dropped in value to about HK$2.2 billion.
Now, Regent, with a three percent stake, is threatening to agitate shareholder support for a restructuring of Hambros involving the spinning off of non-core assets.
"Frankly speaking, the thing is better broken up than left as it is," Mellon said.
Hambros, whose chief executive accused Regent of being "gratuitously rude" after he met a Regent representative last month, has failed to respond publicly to many of Regent's accusations.
Hambros in Hongkong referred calls to its London office, from where there was no immediate comment available.
London-based analysts, who also said Hambros was worth more broken up, cautioned that a buyer was unlikely to surface given the company's poor market performance.
